quoteLast: , I was aroused by a resounding crash.
title: Indians of the Enchanted Desert
author: Crane, Leo, 1881-1960

quoteFirst: To these magnates, railway directors, it seemed but a little matter whether a volunteer regiment or company marched a few additional miles out and home to join a train which could, but would not, pull up at a nearer station. Then the feeding arrangements were decidedly precarious; and as men leaving home
quoteLast: , and not returning until about the same hour next day, all wearing tight uniforms with little room to stow away provisions, would be hungry, it was necessary to ensure a supply of food. Contractors in London had agreed to meet the want, but something at the last moment occurred to upset the arrangement, and on the day previous to starting this battalion found itself unprovided for.
title: The history of the 1st Batt. Wilts Volunteers, from 1861 to 1885
author: Gibney, R. D. (Robert Dwarris), 1826-1906

quoteLast: waiting to be taken to their billets.

quoteFirst: We soon came upon Wishart being carried along on a sheet.  His face was very pale; I gave him a drink from my water bottle, but I scarcely think he knew me.

quoteFirst: My skin became moist and more healthy, and my spirits instead of being depressed became equable and cheerful. No visions haunted my sleep. I could not sleep, however, more than two or three hours at a time, and from
quoteLast: until 8--when I took my opium--I was restless and troubled with a gnawing, twitching sensation in the stomach.  From seventeen grains downward my torment (for by that word alone can I characterize the pangs I endured) commenced.
title: The Opium Habit
author: Day, Horace B., 1819-1870

quoteFirst: On the night of the 14th it rained a little.
quoteLast: the wind blew round to the north-west, and at dawn we had a smart shower which cooled the air, reducing the temperature to something bearable. The sun rose amidst heavy clouds, by which his fiery beams were intercepted in their passage to the earth's surface.
title:
